newsitem.title: USA: FOCUS - API crude build sparks selling, confusion.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - API crude build sparks selling, confusion.

text.p: This week's report from the American Petroleum Institute (API) cut bearishly into energy prices Tuesday evening, but fueled ongoing complaints about the data's credibility, traders said.

Indeed, an off-the-charts crude build of nearly seven million barrels shown in the report sparked a quick 30 cents selloff for June crude in late-day ACCESS trade, but also left traders with a sense the report did not make sense.
"I don't get it," said Gerald Samuels, managing director of ARB Oil.
API said crude stocks stood at 322.6 million barrels at the end of last week, 6.9 million over the prior week, and nearly 23 million over prior year levels.
Samuels and others questioned how stocks could have built so much when refinery utilization rates also rose sharply, and yet crude oil imports did not.

Refinery run rates rose by a completely unexpected 2.4 percentage points last week to a very high 96.7 percent of total capacity, while imports stood at 8.22 million barrels per day (bpd)-- 149,000 bpd less than in API's prior report.
"It's messed up," said another trader in New York.

But the New York trader and others cautioned that despite the report's obvious logical lapses, it also contained unimpeachable bearishness on the gasoline front in the form of a way-above-expectation build of 6.5 million barrels.
"This throws a big bucket of cold water on gasoline bullishness. It kills the demand and stock hype," said Bob MacMinn, president MPAS Inc in Toronto.
Gasoline futures on ACCESS were down by over a cent a gallon to around 63.75 cents a gallon, with the data showing a surprising jump in domestic output to 8.11 million bpd.
Also, the implied demand data came off to 7.48 million bpd per day from the hard-to-believe highs of 8.7 in the API's last report.

A good part of that build was the result of a 2.9 million barrels build of reformulated gasoline stocks on the East Coast, which explains part of the NYMEX selloff since the gasoline contract is deliverable in New York Harbor.

The API's distillate data also provided a bit of a surprise, but on the bullish side of the ledger. The report showed stocks dropping by 1.1 million barrels to 96.5 million barrels against expectations for a build of over two million barrels.
Still, the NYMEX heating oil contract was infected by the broader bearish reactions to the data, with the June contract shedding over 0.50 cent on ACCESS to 55.95 cents a gallon.
"It was pretty wild," ARB's Samuels said of the API report.
-- Oliver Ludwig New York Energy Desk +1 212 859 1633
